author: pospam
content: Leaving decentralized staking injured at the feet of centralized staking is sure to result in centralized staking killing decentralized staking. The point of staking is to secure the network, but the result of rewarding something as easy as staking is that more than necessary will be staked. If decentralized staking is reserved for individuals with 6 figure USD, the masses will pool their money and animate a demagogue. Ethereum consensus can EASILY become centralized because the VAST MAJORITY of eth is held in small chunks. If the best option for this majority is to stake with centralized entities, the masses WILL unfortunately animate a demagogue. Decentralized pooling is injured at the feet of a looming and materializing phantom.

author: djrtwo
content:
I think that the counter arguments on the last eth2 call are valid ‚Äî (1) this only targets coinbase fees on top of the 1559 burn (other MEV has no restriction to go to coinbase) and (2) it just encourages side channels for tx fees and non-coinbase use of mev

In the honest case, it looks like a benefit, but in the honest case, you don‚Äôt need enforcement anyway. In the dishonest case, it encourages side-channel payments/markets and further obfuscates what‚Äôs going on

I‚Äôm not saying there isn‚Äôt a problem for certain validator setups, but I‚Äôm not convinced that 0x02 is a solution

Pretty much any TX and MEV value on top of the 1559 burn is subject to side-channel / non-coinbase payments *no matter what* you put into the base protocol

author: djrtwo
content: even if fees were paid to the validator account itself, you still have this issue. All extractable value from the block can go to the producer of the block through any myriad of channels

author: drdoofus0000
content:
Another way to look at this is via the eth2.0 design goals:

1. Simplicity: minimize complexity, even at the cost of some losses in efficiency

    0x02 proposal removes a hidden/underivable feature (that the ‚Äúwithdrawal‚Äù address isn‚Äôt always *the* withdrawal address). Sure, side-channels will still exist, but a complexity is still reduced.

2. Resilience: remain live through major network partitions and when very large portions of nodes go offline

    0x02 or adding the functionality to 0x01 doesn‚Äôt violate this

3. Longevity: select all components such that they are either quantum secure or can be easily swapped out for quantum secure counterparts when available

    0x02 or adding the functionality to 0x01 doesn‚Äôt violate this

4. Security: utilize crypto and design techniques that allow for a large participation of validators in total and per unit time

    This type of security might be provided by the security one gets with less avenues to hijack their coinbase payments without them knowing

5. Decentralization: allow for a typical consumer laptop with O(C) resources to process/validate O(1) shards (including any system level validation such as the beacon chain)

    0x02 promotes more decentralized validators (maybe this is opinion) or at least discourages low eth stakers from going for the easy centralized route that also offers higher returns

author: djrtwo
content: As for (1), this introduces consensus complexity whereas it is unclear if it solves the problem

author: djrtwo
content: I'm worried it creates a *false* sense of security

author: izz.y
content: People who are going to hog all MEV/priority fees possible would do it regardless of 0x02 or not. This doesn't create an "extra" incentive. All it does is create additional work required for them to do it (and benefit from other peoples' staked eth) in order to do so. If in the dishonest case it prevents >0% of the dishonest actors from acting due to the increased complexity of setting up a side-channel vs a simple coinbase address change then I think it's worth it.

author: djrtwo
content: especially for the MEV component of fees which has *zero* requirement to go to COINBASE

author: izz.y
content: It has zero requirement but the general (commonplace) mechanism that most node operators will use will depend on the "preconfigured"/default configurations provided. The question then becomes how easy <-> complex is it to deviate from this default mechanism

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: main argument that made sense to me is that if a honest validator gets hacked, the hacker often wont bother to (or even know how to) modify it and establish a sidechannel for MEV

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: esp if hacker is not crypto-targeted

author: izz.y
content: I think this is a valid concern but isn't really a reason to *not* do it. Does it add security vs not having it (especially w.r.t. the general security risk of a hacker surreptitiously changing a coinbase address)? Yes. Can it create a false sense of security? Potentially, which is why this (what 0x02 does and how it works, and what it doesn't do) should be clearly documented and explained.
